title: Jamie Clements tells ICAC Kaila Murnain 'hates my guts'
text:
On more than 50 times when Mr Clements was asked about his role in fundraising he said it was Ms Murnain’s responsibility and that he never got involved in the details unless she raised a problem with him, “which she never did”.

'She was highly capable'

Mr Clements agreed that he had delegated the role of fundraising and the responsibility for it to Ms Murnain, but he had no records of this and he could not recall when he had done this in 2014.

“So you really didn’t know what she was doing?” Mr Robertson asked.

“She was highly capable, you gave her a task she got it done,” Mr Clements said.

He said raising money for election campaigns was a very small part of the overall operation of the office and he only spoke to Ms Murnain is there was a specific problem: “I couldn’t micro manage Kaila about this.”

Chief Commissioner Peter Hall QC asked: “How did that operate? Did she just make it up as she went?”

“I had faith in her to get it done,” Mr Clements said. He said he was never involved in details.

Advertisement

“Nobody knew that office better than Kaila. Nobody was able to master details better than Kaila.”

Mr Robertson suggested Mr Clements was “attempting to distance yourself from any fundraising matter because you know they are of concern to this commission?”

“No, I’m answering questions honestly,” he said.

On Monday, ICAC was told that after Mr Clements stepped down as state secretary in January 2016 Mr Huang engaged him as a consultant on a $200,000 a year retainer and provided him with a rent-free office.

'Best that we all tell the truth'

Meanwhile, family members of former Labor candidate Jonathan Yee have terminated links with the Emperor’s Garden restaurant in Sydney's Chinatown, in the aftermath of a series of disastrous appearances before ICAC.

Jonathan Yee . . . his name is off the family business after ICAC testimony. Wolter Peeters

On October 3, Jonathan Yee, his brother Valentine and their mother, May Ho Yee, all resigned as directors of the operating company, Emperor's Garden, and transferred their shares to the family patriarch, Stanley Yee, who founded the business 40 years ago.

Advertisement

The company filings came a day after Jonathan Yee finished giving evidence before ICAC about his role in disguising $100,000 in donations, which Mr Huang is alleged to have handed to the then state secretary Mr Clements at Labor’s Sussex Street head office in April 2015.

On September 16, Valentine Yee in a humiliating backdown dramatically changed his earlier evidence at ICAC and admitted helping to hide the source of the $100,000 donation, at the urging of state Labor politician Ernest Wong.

Valentine Yee said he told the Yee family at a meeting in a private room at the Emperor’s Garden the previous day: "I think it's best that we all tell the truth."

Last week, Jonathan Yee told ICAC he met Mr Wong at the Chinese Masonic Society in Surry Hills on September 15 and told him "we can no longer tell lies because ... the shit has hit the fan" and his brother Valentine was going to "spill the beans" in his evidence at the ICAC.

Mr Yee said that Mr Wong had asked to speak to his father, Stanley Yee, who had told Mr Wong to “piss off” and “stop ‘effing’ with my family”.

Mr Wong has denied any role in preparing false donor forms.

Patricia Siu, a cashier and waitress at Emperor's Garden, Teresa Tam, a casual waitress, former manager Lei Mo, and former assistant manager Johnnie Lin, have subsequently all told ICAC that they had given false evidence that they were donors, at the instigation of Jonathan Yee.
description: Former NSW Labor secretary Jamie Clements was accused of hating his former assistant secretary Kaila Murnain as he told a corruption inquiry he had no significant role in raising funds, which he left entirely to Ms Murnain.
